column4: trying to install drivers for my wireless card, any idea why i get this error? http://pastebin.com/497439
or anyone feel like walking me through the installation
or anyone know of a page that has information on installing http://www.ralinktech.com/supp-1.htm
i followed the readme exactly.... no luck
it isn't in the correct directory.  Not sure how it got that way, though.
forward slashes on real computers, not back slashes
i dont even think i was supposed to use that switch... but even if i dont i get the same error
there is no way you can get kerneldriversnet (concatenated like that) without supplying it somewhere.  configure doesn't invent strings of that sort.
i dont get what you are saying it shows up as Module install directory : /lib/modules/2.6.12-10-386/kernel/drivers/net to me
in that case, you can't get the same error.
you said you get the same error, which would mean you get an error message with kerneldriversnet with no slashes in it.
http://pastebin.com/497456
i'd have to see the configure file.  almost always that sort of error is caused by an undefined macro.
if you like, sure, I'll take a look at it.  it may or may not help, but you have nothing to lose.
http://pastebin.com/497463
what was the line number again?  I closed the previous paste.
where is that install directory it is talking about? or i guess where does it expect it to be?
wherever the source is unpacked.
ordinarily the same directory that configure is run from, although not always
cause idont think i ever copied Makefile
no, the makefile is generated by ./configure
I see what's happening.  when it asks for the linux kernel source directory, you have to give it the linux kernel source directory.  Either you, or some script, is giving it "make install"
do i need to unpack that?
you did, or a script you ran did, because configure is inside the source directory
no, you can't get this far without first unpacking
are you typing "make install" ?
yes
it looks like, where you type that, you should be typing something like /usr/src/..... (wherever the kernel source lives)
ubuntu keeps the kernel source in a different directory (different than all the other distros)
-r'\kernel\drivers\net ?
no -r, no backslashes, and that's a _driver_ directory, you want the kernel source directory
first, do you have the kernel source installed?
.....i dont know
go into synaptic and find and install it.  If it is already installed, you'll see that in synaptic
oh.. i am using kubuntu if that matters
but i know thats the same as adept
for this case kubuntu and ubuntu are identical
is it linux-source?
that doesn't sound right.  I'm pretty sure you'll find the word "kernel" in the package name
kernel-package?
keep going.  the kernel _source_ is in a separate package.
doesnt find anything for kernel source
let me check the nname
ok
on my box I have kernel-source-2.6.11 and kernel-source-2.6.10
mine says linux-source-2.6.12
good.  But you said you didn't have one.  :)
do uname -a, make sure you are running 2.6.12
it says it is installed though
in that case, you need to type the kernel source path where you were typing "make install" before
look in /usr/src and find the source directory name
does it matter if it is just linux headers
linux source is there, but it is compressed
ok, then extract it.  you know how?
extract it into /usr/src.  then configure should find it without asking you for the path
hopefully, anyway.  you have to extract it regardless.
i think last time i tried i got permission denied, how do i do it from command line so i can use sudo
why can't you use sudo?
from konqueror, i cannot
how do you unzip something from command line?
then do it from the command line.
it is probably a tar.bz2
yep
if so, you type:  tar xvjf whatever.tar.bz2
what is xvjf for?
x means extract, v means verbose, j means uncompress with bzip2, and f means you have a tar file.
ah thanks
f is an anachronism.  tar means "tape archiver" and without an f it looks for a tape drive
ah...
woo extracting
ok thats all done, do i go and do make install again?
try it.  ordinarily configure is run first, but if that's what the instructions call for, then yes, do that.
yeah it says make config first
seems like the same error
make: binary operator expected
then you'll have to type in the directory name.
if you type "make install" at that point, you'll always get the same result
ah.. what directory?
it prompts you for the kernel source directory.  give it the kernel source directory
oh
so like make usr/src.linux-source-2.6.12/install ?
I'm not sure I don't have it in front of me.  However, /usr, not just usr.
alright
normally the argument to make is a target.
what I saw in the configure script is that it prompts for the kernel path.  that may be hidden within a script.
nothing is working
try the normal way to install source, which is:  ./configure
as step one.  in the source directory.  assuming you know where that is
http://pastebin.com/497474
make /usr/src/linux-2.6.12-10-386 a symbolic link to the actually kernel source directory.
i have that to
then what you extracted is not the kernel source
timfrost should i try this one?
